ProcedureOptionHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: CONFIG="file-path"
      
Specifies the path to a file that provides the connection parameters to S3.

Syntax: KEYID="aws-key-id"
      
Specifies the AWS access key ID (a 20-character, alphanumeric string). For example: AKIAIOSFODNN7EXAMPLE.

Syntax: SECRET="aws-secret"
      
Specifies the AWS secret access key (a 40-character string). 

For example: wJalrXUtnFEMI/K7MDENG/bPxRfiCYEXAMPLEKEY.

The secret= value is supposed to be secret, so secure it with OS controls like chmod 700 /u/$USER/.tks3.conf.

Syntax: REGION="aws-region"specifies the AWS region to connect to. 
      
Accepted values are as follows:  
   "usstd"
   "useast" 
   "uswest" 
   "uswestca" 
   "euireland" 
   "eufrankfurt" 
   "apsingapore" 
   "apsydney" 
   "aptokyo" 
   "sa" 
   "usgov" 
   "fips"

StatementHelp.#cdata:
Syntax: COPY "source-s3-location" "destination-s3-location";

where:

source-s3-location
  specifies a source path in S3 that is fully qualified from the bucket name to the object name. 
  
destination-s3-location
  specifies a destination path in S3 that is fully qualified from the bucket name to the object name.

Syntax: CREATE "bucket-name";
      
where:

bucket-name
  specifies a bucket name. Unless you are using the CREATE statement, the bucket must already exist. 
  Bucket names must be unique across all of S3.

Syntax: DELETE "s3-location";

where:

s3-location
  specifies a path in S3 that is fully qualified from the bucket name to the object name.
  Common object types for use with SAS are files and directories.

Syntax: DESTROY "bucket-name";
      
where:

bucket-name
  specifies a bucket name. The bucket must already exist. Bucket names must be unique across all of S3.

Syntax: GET "s3-location" <"local-path">;
      
where:

s3-location
  specifies a path in S3 that is fully qualified from the bucket name to the object name. 
  Common object types for use with SAS are files and directories.
  
"local-path"
  specifies a file or directory that is local to the SAS client. Examples are c:\public for Windows and /u/$USER/ for Linux.

Syntax: GETDIR "s3-location" "local-path";

where:

s3-location
  specifies a path in S3 that is fully qualified from the bucket name to the object name. 
  Common object types for use with SAS are files and directories.
  
"local-path"
  specifies a file or directory that is local to the SAS client. Examples are c:\public for Windows and /u/$USER/ for Linux.

Syntax: INFO "s3-location";

where:

s3-location
  specifies a path in S3 that is fully qualified from the bucket name to the object name.
  Common object types for use with SAS are files and directories.

Syntax: LIST <_SHORT_> "s3-location";

where:

_SHORT_ 
  specifies short list format. (?)

s3-location
  specifies a path in S3 that is fully qualified from the bucket name to the object name.
  Common object types for use with SAS are files and directories.

Syntax: MKDIR "s3-location";

where:

s3-location
  specifies a path in S3 that is fully qualified from the bucket name to the object name.
  Common object types for use with SAS are files and directories.

Syntax: PUT "local-path" "s3-location";

where:

"local-path"
  specifies a file or directory that is local to the SAS client. Examples are c:\public for Windows and /u/$USER/ for Linux.
  
s3-location
  specifies a path in S3 that is fully qualified from the bucket name to the object name. 
  Common object types for use with SAS are files and directories.

Syntax: PUTDIR "local-path" "s3-location";

where:

"local-path"
  specifies a file or directory that is local to the SAS client. Examples are c:\public for Windows and /u/$USER/ for Linux.
  
s3-location
  specifies a path in S3 that is fully qualified from the bucket name to the object name. 
  Common object types for use with SAS are files and directories.

Syntax: RMDIR "s3-location";

where:

s3-location
  specifies a path in S3 that is fully qualified from the bucket name to the object name.
  Common object types for use with SAS are files and directories.
